captions.text:
Yo what it do? This week on Thug
Notes we gettin lovestruck with
Romeo and Juliet by William Shakespeare.
Up in the swanky part of Verona,

two families called the Montagues and the
Capulets been beefin since forever.

After dodging an all out war in the streets,
Big Daddy Montague and his boo Lady Montague

start talkin bout
their emo son Romeo who got it BAD for some

fox Rosaline. But Rosaline ain’t feelin
it, and now Romeo mopin around like dun lost

his nuts.
So Romeo’s homios Benvolio and

Mercutio try to get his mind off that trick
by crashing a party over at the Capulet crib.

But as soon as Romeo peeps the most-
tappable ass of Juliet Capulet, he forgets

all about bout dat Rosaline mess and steps
up to holler.

Romeo loves himself some fast
women, so he drops his A game, gets a lil

lip action, and snags those digits.
Then Romeo creeps up to Juliet’s

balcony. Turns out, she batsh** crazy in love
with him too! But since their families got

such beef, they gotta keep it on the DL.
Next day, Romeo and Juliet run off

to the local preacher man Friar Lawrence’s
spot and get hitched.Later, Benvolio and Mercutio

takin
it easy when Tybalt, the baddest mofo of all

da Capulets, steps to and starts talkin sh**.
Mercutio boot up and start scrappin with Tybalt

til Romeo busts in and tries to break it up.
But Romeo just gets in the way and Tybalt

shanks Mercutio. Romeo goes from whiny bitch
to hard-ass thug and straight MERCS Tybalt.

The Prince of Verona HAD IT with
all this gang violence. So he boots Romeo

right outta town.
When Juliet’s mama say she gotta marry some

candy-ass scrub named
Paris, Juliet gets all torn up and hits up

Friar Lawrence for some help.
Fry-daddy comes with a plan to fake

Juliet’s death by giving her some joose
that make her take a long ass nap. Then he

gonna write Romeo a letter sayin all he has
to do is play it cool, and once Juliet wakes,

Romeo will have a lifetime supply of poon-tang.
Problem is, the letter never makes

it to Romeo. So when he hears Juliet bit the
dust, he thinks its fo real.

Romeo straight flips. So he rolls
up to Juliet’s crypt, peeps her layin stiff,

and throws back some poision. When Juliet
wakes up and sees his dead body, she gets

all crunk, grabs a knife, and kills herself.
Teenagers man..

Peep this motif, blood. Willy
Shakes flippin opposites all up in this play.

Love/hate, youth/age, life/death- I ain’t
even trippin.

Even characters got opposites. For
example, while Benvolio be all chill and peace-loving,

Tybalt always coming out hard tryin to throw
down. Sh***t you can even peep these paradoxes
in tha text, B.

But Willy ain't just playin - all these clashing opposites makin dat dramatic
action mo intense.

Listen up, padna. The full title of
this play is “The Most Excellent and Lamentable

Tragedy of Romeo and Juliet.” Cept is it
really a tragedy? Some homies don’t think

so.
See in most tragedies, the

characters got somethin in their dome that’s
so fu**ed up that no matter what they gonna

end up feeling the hurt. Peeps call this “the
tragic flaw.”

Thing is, some thugz say Romeo and
Juliet ain’t rollin with no tragic flaws.

It ain’t their fault that sh** gets so cray.
But what is tragic is that something else

is tripping up their game- chance.
All throughout this play, fate doin

our lovers straight dirty.
Just look at all these ridiculous

coincidences: Dat letter don’t find Romeo,
The Friar too late in stopping him, Juliet

wakes up RIGHT AFTER Romeo bites the big one.
I could go on playa.

So when the prologue sayin that
these kids be “star-crossed,” maybe it’s

cuz the heavens got it in for these fools.
But maybe it ain’t fate so much as

it is kids actin like stupid lil sh**s. Some
say Romeo and Juliet’s tragic flaw be a

love all insane in the membrane. And they
willin to do ANYTHING to keep it real. Even

Friar Lawrence say that sh** a sin-
Could be that it ain’t that they

sinnin at all, but that the world they live
in just too twisted to deal wit a love as

pure as theirs. Maybe it ain’t our lovers
that got flaws, son. Maybe it’s the world.

But all scholars agree it would be
a damn tragedy if you didn’t Subscribe.
Peace, yall!

comments.author: Abyalew Bayu

comments.text:
I strongly disagree that Romeo and Juliet don't possess a tragic flaw. 
 They fell in love without knowing anything about each other as people, 
suggesting what they thought was love, was really lust.  I would argue this 
view is supported by the fact that Romeo was in love with someone else at 
the start of the play, but forgot all about her when he saw Juliet.  Like a 
lot of youngsters, the unhappy couple were more in love with being in love 
than they were with each other.  Since this foolhardy love is what 
ultimately causes their deaths, I think it's fair to say that this play 
falls perfectly into the tragic genre. 

Some might argue that their love should be taken as real because love at 
first sight was a common occurrence in stories of that time.  But I would 
argue that Shakespeare was simply ahead of his time, as are all great 
artists.﻿

For me I always thought the tragedy was in the youthful rashness and 
rebellion. Face it people these two are full of it. Especially Romeo, I 
hate that useless cryer. They fall hopelessly in love and kill themselves 
in less than a week. That wasn't love they just wanted to experience 
something as exciting and new as a whirlwind romance. What's tragic is that 
if I stopped Juliet before she stabbed herself and asked her what Romeo's 
favorite color was she wouldn't be able to answer me. The play is basically 
a long PSA asking people to actually stop and think before they do stuff 
that ruins their lives.﻿

comments.text:
+Jaquie Graham "They were a lot more mature than the children we see 
today." No, they really REALLY weren't. They died for each other for the 
sake of rebelling against their families and nothing more. It didn't have 
anything to do with love because they only knew each other for a handful of 
days at most. That's like the antithesis of maturity.
comments.author: Fatboyftw32

comments.text:
+Jaquie Graham Where do you get that Romeo was 16?  Where do you get that 
they were more mature?  Romeo goes from pining for Rosaline one night to 
pining for Juliet the next.  This is mature?  This is ready for marriage? 
 And Juliet?  Raised by a seriously confused nurse and an absolutely 
clueless mother--they are going to marry Juliet to Paris for the political 
connections, not for her maturity.  

You miss Shakespeare's point.  He is trying to show how Italians have it 
all wrong about marriage--how they are hot-blooded both in battle and in 
the sack.  The English at the time would have thought Romeo and Juliet's 
actions scandalous--hardly the actions of mature children.
comments.author: David Stevens

comments.text:
They were 14 and 16, but you have to keep in mind that back in the day, 
they were adults at that age. They were ready to marry.  Remember that the 
Capulets were planning for Juliet to marry Paris.  People keep referring to 
them as teenagers, but they were a lot more mature than the children we see 
today.
comments.author: Jaquie Graham

comments.text:
Welllllll, I don't think it was that simple.  First, remember they are 
"star-crossed" lovers, which doesn't mean they were starry-eyed for each 
other, nor does it mean that they were simply unlucky--it means that the 
gods, the fates, the stars, or whatever deity you choose, has ruled that a 
love like theirs (lust) is not sanctioned, not healthy, and won't ever work 
out in the long run.  There are many evidences that they were in lust, not 
love, including Romeo's recent pining for Rosaline, whom he claims to love, 
but then falls for Juliet on sight.  And let's not forget Juliet's 
shallowness--not really her fault--but consider her training from a ditzy 
mom, a bumbling dad, and a completely rustic and backwards Nurse, who knows 
more about Juliet's birthday than her own mother!!

But don't forget all the other things going on in the play.  Juliet was 
already presumed dead.  She had little to gain by resurrecting--she'd have 
a lot of explaining to do (like why she was no longer a virgin, and she 
would also have to criminally implicate The Friar and The Nurse in the 
aiding and abetting of Romeo's escape) and she also would then have to 
marry Paris (a man she found most repulsive).  So, she had motives other 
than "love."

Romeo also had motives other than "love."  The Prince had already decreed 
that it was death to Romeo if he was found in Verona because he murdered 
Tybalt, so he was a dead man walking anyway--and he'd also have some 
explaining to do, which would criminally implicate The Friar, The Nurse and 
possibly Benvolio, not to mention The Apothecary.  

So, while many modern versions of ROMEO AND JULIET like to make it a 
romance, claiming their two-day teenage fling was some kind of love worthy 
to die for, I say we stick to Shakespeare's text and call it what he called 
it: The Tragedy of Romeo and Juliet.
comments.author: David Stevens

comments.text:
Personally, I think they were very in love. Romeo killed himself because he 
thought Juliet was actually dead. Juliet did the same. If I found out the 
guy I was sleeping with had killed himself, I don't think I would take my 
life. But hey, we're all meant to get something different out of this story.
comments.author: meghantherese21

comments.text:
Oh, that's okay.  I was hoping you had found something I'd been missing for 
years!  It happens--my students do it all the time.  Oh well--yeah.  We 
just have to guess.  Really the point is that he's not really in love. 
 He's a teenage boy wanting to get . . . well . . . what teenage boys want 
to get from a teenage girl.  And the point of the play, IMHO, is that 
Shakespeare is trying to show how hot-headed those derned Italians are, and 
how outrageously young they set them up for marriage, and how nutty they 
can be in general when it comes to important things like marriage and 
family relationships--and, finally that is great to be living in Merrie 
Olde England, where we have it all figured out.
comments.author: David Stevens

comments.text:
My mistake, I'm thinking of a different book. It doesn't state his age, 
only Juliet's (2 weeks away from her 14th birthday) But Romeo has been 
thought to be around the age 15-17. Sorry for my ignorance
comments.author: meghantherese21

comments.text: Where does it say this?  Act and scene, please!
comments.author: David Stevens

comments.text:
You said you made a guess at his age... It says right in the story he's 17 
haha. Don't believe me? Oh well
comments.author: meghantherese21

comments.text:
+meghantherese21 Where do you get 17?  I don't want to pull rank, but I've 
been teaching this play since 1995.  Romeo's age is never actually given, 
only that he's a "youth."  I grant you that my guess of Romeo's age is just 
that--a guess.  But, based on a lot of things that Mercutio, Benvolio, and 
the rest of the gang say, he's quite a bit younger than they are.  So, I've 
made a guess at his age--probably 14 or 15.
comments.author: David Stevens

comments.author: Adam Edwards

comments.text:
This was almost a perfect rendering!!!! The summaries of each act and the 
graphics were just the right amount of information for students to process. 
Just enough was kept to maintain the integrity of the story, while just 
enough was taken away to use this as a companion to the actual play, which 
they sometimes find difficult to read. I wanted to show this to my 
students, but unfortunately, it is not appropriate. I could not even get 
through the entire piece myself because of the language. I have some pretty 
urban students in my class, for lack of a better word, who really would 
have enjoyed seeing this too because the narration is done by a gentleman 
of color and in the vernacular that some of them often speak and hear 
outside of school. WHY, oh WHY, oh WHY did it have to have profanity in it? 
I guess maybe that is thug speak, but this is story primarily read by high 
school freshmen. Although it has some great points, I would not feel 
comfortable and cannot show this in my class. There are no expletives in 
the play. Besides all that, we are trying to encourage our students to use 
appropriate language in school, public, work settings, etc., vs the 
language they might use while talking to good friends, or socially outside 
of school. There's a place for everything. Some of my guys in class would 
really get into the play with it put like this and you have done nearly all 
of the classics as I glance at the list to the right! Perhaps you could 
work on a school appropriate version (on all levels because the animation, 
the narrator, the story analysis and recounting are great, but the 
cursing....). Of course I guess I should not be so shocked because the 
definition of the word 'thug' is "violent criminal, brutal ruffian and 
assassin." It's a shame. My students are so into this image...Why can't we 
have the toughness, the humor, the slang even, without the offensive? I 
wish you all the best. ﻿

comments.author: Rebi

comments.text:
In my mind the tragedy is partially that the love they sacrifice their 
lives for is ultimately passion and little else.  They never once have a 
chance to grow as a couple, learn each other's interests, or even know much 
about the other's personality.  Instead, they've fallen for beauty and 
forbidden fruit.

In the end, Romeo and Juliet are undone by chance in a world that would not 
allow them to discover if the love they felt was real or just a passing 
fling.﻿
